an11.13:4.1: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Sakyans, near Kapilavatthu in the Banyan Tree Monastery.
an11.13:4.2: Now at that time the Buddha wanted to enter the rainy season residence at Sāvatthī.
an11.13:5.1: Nandiya the Sakyan heard about this,
an11.13:5.4: “Why don’t I also enter the rains residence at Sāvatthī.
an11.13:5.5: There I can engage in work and from time to time get to see the Buddha.”
an11.13:6.1: So the Buddha entered the rains residence in Sāvatthī,
an11.13:6.3: There he engaged in work and from time to time got to see the Buddha.
an11.13:6.4: At that time several mendicants were making a robe for the Buddha, thinking that
an11.13:6.5: when his robe was finished and the three months of the rains residence had passed the Buddha would set out wandering.
an11.13:7.1: Nandiya the Sakyan heard about this.
an11.13:7.4: He went up to the Buddha,
an11.13:7.5: bowed, sat down to one side,
an11.13:7.8: several mendicants are making a robe for the Buddha, thinking that
an11.13:7.9: when his robe was finished and the three months of the rains residence had passed the Buddha would set out wandering.
an11.13:7.10: Now, we spend our life in various ways. Which of these should we practice?”
an11.13:8.2: It’s appropriate that respectable people such as you come to me and ask:
an11.13:8.3: ‘We spend our life in various ways. Which of these should we practice?’
an11.13:8.4: The faithful succeed, not the faithless.
an11.13:8.5: The ethical succeed, not the unethical.
an11.13:8.6: The energetic succeed, not the lazy.
an11.13:8.7: The mindful succeed, not the unmindful.
an11.13:8.8: Those with samādhi succeed, not those without samādhi.
an11.13:8.9: The wise succeed, not the witless.
an11.13:8.10: When you’re grounded on these six things, go on to develop five further things.
an11.13:9.1: Firstly, you should recollect the Realized One:
an11.13:9.2: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme trainer of people, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’
an11.13:9.3: In this way you should establish mindfulness internally based on the Realized One.
an11.13:10.1: Furthermore, you should recollect the teaching:
an11.13:10.2: ‘The teaching is well explained by the Buddha—realizable in this very life, immediately effective, inviting inspection, relevant, so that sensible people can know it for themselves.’
an11.13:10.3: In this way you should establish mindfulness internally based on the teaching.
an11.13:11.1: Furthermore, you should recollect your good friends:
an11.13:11.2: ‘I’m fortunate, so very fortunate, to have good friends who advise and instruct me out of kindness and compassion.’
an11.13:11.3: In this way you should establish mindfulness internally based on good friends.
an11.13:12.1: Furthermore, you should recollect your own generosity:
an11.13:12.2: ‘I’m so fortunate, so very fortunate. Among people heart full of the stain of stinginess I live at home rid of stinginess, freely generous, open-handed, loving to let go, committed to charity, loving to give and to share.’
an11.13:12.3: In this way you should establish mindfulness internally based on generosity.
an11.13:13.1: Furthermore, you should recollect the gods:
an11.13:13.2: ‘There are gods who, surpassing the company of gods that consume solid food, are reborn in a certain group of mind-made gods. They don’t see in themselves anything more to do, or anything that needs improvement.’
an11.13:13.3: A permanently freed mendicant doesn’t see in themselves anything more to do, or anything that needs improvement.
an11.13:13.4: In the same way, Nandiya, there are gods who, surpassing the company of gods that consume solid food, are reborn in a certain group of mind-made gods. They don’t see in themselves anything more to do, or anything that needs improvement.
an11.13:13.5: In this way you should establish mindfulness internally based on the gods.
an11.13:14.1: A noble disciple who has these eleven qualities gives up bad, unwholesome qualities and doesn’t cling to them.
an11.13:14.2: It’s like when a pot full of water is tipped over, so the water drains out and doesn’t go back in.
an11.13:14.3: Suppose there was an uncontrolled fire. It advances burning up dry woodlands and doesn’t go back over what it’s burned.
an11.13:14.4: In the same way, a noble disciple who has these eleven qualities gives up bad, unwholesome qualities and doesn’t cling to them.”
